summary: Hidden inside a smartphone, the bustling city of Textopolis is home to all emojis. Each emoji has only one facial expression, except for Gene, an exuberant emoji with multiple expressions. Determined to become "normal" like the other emojis, Gene enlists the help of his best friend Hi-5 and a notorious code breaker called Jailbreak. During their travels through the other apps, the three emojis discover a great danger that could threaten their phone's very existence.

If you're looking for a great use of your time then The Emoji Movie is the way to go. I recently watched this movie and to put it plainly, it was like watching a(n) Bird Run. A totally Amazing experience.

Directed by Tony Leondis and starring T.J Miller & James Corden, The Emoji Movie told a completely Stunning story.

The Emoji Movie is a(n) Comedy movie about characters who embark on a journey of having real friends is more important than being popular, and that good friends will help out even when things are hard.. Despite the obstacles, big and small, the characters in the movie, as well as the viewers, still meet a great end. The performances from T.J Miller & James Corden illustrate the narrative of this movie with such a viable effort. Consequently, this film ended up being as Beautiful as it is.

The Emoji Movie intertwined visuals, audio, and plot in a very Amazing way.

It was as if Tony Leondis combined the characters, the setting, and the valued objects within the film and then threw them into a mixing bowl to create a giant serving of great Spaghetti. As a viewer, chewing and pondering on the quality of my Spaghetti, I couldn't help but think about how sweet it tasted. The flavors of the film blended so great-ly that I considered getting a(n) Bird for emotional support!

This story of having real friends is more important than being popular, and that good friends will help out even when things are hard. is a triumphant effort on Tony Leondis's part in making viewers weep with joy.

Overall, I found The Emoji Movie to be Amazing, Stunning, and Beautiful! It is a great plate of Spaghetti, seasoned with the theme of having real friends is more important than being popular, and that good friends will help out even when things are hard., and sure to leave you with a lingering sweet taste in your mouth.

Where to begin, where to begin! You know a movie is outstanding when the end credits alone are more epic than the majority of films released in the last 20 years! This film is the pure definition of an emotional roller coaster and throughout it's run time brings about fascination, humor, sadness, incredible excitement, and sheer finality. This is not your typical comedy movie and some viewers used to the entertaining, nonstop action style of the previous films may be disappointed, but I think that this movie brilliantly satisfies and subverts expectations. 

The film's storytelling is some of the best ever seen in blockbuster filmaking, combining smart writing, intimate character moments, and exceptional world building to create one of the best blockbuster stories ever. The superheroes are all brilliantly acted and well written, with James Corden, Patrick Stewart, and T.J Miller in particular turning in some of the most human and enduring acting preformances I have ever seen. In addition, Patrick Stewart once again proves utterly breathtaking as "Poop". Further proving that "Poop" is definitely among the very best movie villains of the last century.

The action is honestly some of the finest in the history of cinema. The world renowned final battle of this film is riveting, heartbreaking, awe inspiring, and exceptionally well choreographed. Never before have I been so thoroughly moved and elated while watching a battle scene in film. The film's soundtrack is also one of the best of it's kind and brilliantly complements the action. It is filled with some of the most stunning, blood pumping, and epic music themes you will EVER hear.

Some Potential but horribly flawed execution.  The voice acting was okay. The Animation showed some creativity to it and was lively and colorful in spurts but most of the time was cheaply done, uninspired a lot of times and uninteresting. The editing and pacing was very hit or miss with the whole middle of the movie being extremely boring and forgettable because of nothing but constant product advertisements. The jokes are extremely hit or miss also with most missing. There also some plot holes in the story as well. The idea has some creative potential and there is some flashes of originality here and there but the good is far far outweighed by the boring, uninspired and generic characters, animation and lack of charm. Avoid it.

This movie was so diabolical that I came out of the movie theatre with a two-day migraine. Both can convey feelings and thoughts, but neither are an adequate subject for a movie. The personified emojis just aren't a good medium to convey more complex human emotions. The best part of the movie were the credits. This movie could be enjoyable for masochists.

This has to be some of the worst writing used in a animated movie that rips off films like Wreck it Ralph and Inside Out with no originality a highly mean spirited tone, God awful humor a message that coming from this film is hypocritical soulless advertising placed everywhere like Candy Crush, Just Dance, Spotify, YouTube, Twitter and more, an utterly despicable need to be cool with the young crowd, a cast of such hateable characters, lazy voice acting and to top it all off, Animation that's conceptually so bad that no professional studio would ever allow it on the big screen, in embodies every single creative problem with Sony Pictures Animation and present them all in this one disastrous feature. In fact 2017 in general was the prime example of everything wrong with Sony Pictures Animation for both the creative and business side with releases like Smurfs the lost village (although pretty decent), Surfs Up 2 WaveMania (but I really like WWE) The Star (for ripping off Jesus) and their Cloudy with a chance of Meatballs and Hotel Translvania tv shows. To be honest, I saw The Emoji Movie only to understand why it gets so much hate. As a Redditor I understand why I am supposed to hate this movie (because...emojis?), but why does the normie audience hate it? Isn't this movie supposed to be like, their dream come true? Don't they always keep spamming emojis in all their sentences when writing a message or making a meme? When the movie hadn't come out it was being advertised a lot, so I thought people are supposed to be excited. Even the animation of this movie seemed really good. But I watched it and now I know the problem.
The Emoji Movie is very ignorant. It talks about emojis as if it is supposed to be something very cool. In reality only elders, women and children use emojis when they message (because they are the only ones we can't slap some sense into). But then again the target audience here is the children. So considering this movie is from their point of view, emojis are supposed to be shown as though they mean a lot to them. So let's come to the second point. The emojis are shown to have their entire personality revolving around their expression. Why can't they just be doing their job? Also how come so many emojis look similar? Is it like only one of them goes to the emoji keyboard while the others have no business? There are so many questions that the movie doesn't answer.
I don't know which problem plagues this movie the most. Is it the product placement? No, it just gives a feeling of adventure. None of the product placement looks as much on the nose as everyone describes. Like in TVF Originals they straight up speak out to advertise the things. Here at least Gene and Hi-5 are going to those places to see what is happening over there. I kinda found the Candy Crush part funny and relaxing at the same time. There was also the Just Dance part, and that was definitely cringy. But that was the only cringy one. Facebook, Skype, Drop Box - everything else was quite decent.
The jokes weren't half as bad, considering this is aimed for kids. Even I used to make many poop jokes when I was 13. If there even was anything bad, the animation and music compensated for it. The idea that there are so many emojis that we can establish and entire world using it is actually something I'm guessing everyone must have thought at some point. The one part that I surely felt was cringy was when the kid gets to ask out his crush because he sent her a custom emoji. Only if life functioned that easily. Hi-5 was also pretty disgusting. Every time he kept his hand (thumb) down it used to hurt me. Imagine bending your thumb down that much. Also when he ate the salivated candy I felt like vomiting.
The Emoji Movie is a bad movie, yes, but it's still better than many animated movies I have seen. Food Fight, Delhi Safari, Roadside Romeo, Geng: The Adventure Begins, Pangaa Gang, the entire Super Bheem series - there are plenty of examples of animated movies that are even worse than this. It does have redeeming qualities, even if they are not enough to make this a genuinely good movie. I can imagine the animators must have worked hard on this movie even if they didn't agree with the script. And that is the reason why I have massive respect for them.

When I first saw this movie with my two younger kids, they had a fun time watching the movie. However, I was practically clawing my eyes out over the sloppy plot, mostly unlikeable characters, odd dialogue, random plot jumps/jumping to random side plots that have no actual meaning, and mostly forgettable scenes. The only thing the movie had going for it, besides the crap ton of celebrity voice actors (because every single animated kids movie nowadays just don't survive without the celebrity actors), is the animation. It's Sony, the animation is going to be at least somewhat good.

After watching this a second time by myself, just to make sure that what I saw the first time wasn't just me having a fever dream, it became very very clear to me that, even with their 50 million dollar budget, something went horribly wrong. Either the animators weren't given enough time (which I doubt because the Emoji Movie took 2 whole years to make), or the writers didn't know how they could make a movie about emojis that would actually work in the box office, which is understandable.

I assume that the Emoji Movie was made to try to appeal to kids or teens by, of course, having emojis as the main characters. But, that was already a big mistake. as my older kid who confirmed that kids and teens nowadays rarely ever use emojis, but rather emoticons. In the movie, the emoticons are referred to as the elderly, which I assume makes enough sense. There's no real way to fix this though, as an animated movie all about emojis or emoticons would still be a huge failure, no matter what.

Overall, this movie was destined to fail the moment it began production. After viewing the movie twice, I thought to myself, 'Man, Hollywood really screwed up this time. I hope they'll be able to fix themselves up down the road.'. I thought that Hollywood would learn their lesson and not do that again, and for the most part, they did! But then, CATS happened. Oh god, was that movie an absolute disaster. I haven't watched it, and I never will, but from the trailers alone, that movie honestly scares me.

NOPE. I even thought when first seeing the trailers for this movie that it could've had potential, but decided to waste it all with a terrible storyline that steals from other movies, characters that give the movie an extra mean-spirited lair, animation that doesn't even look professional at all in comparison to other movies Sony has produced, terrible humor and worst of all...CONSTANT shameless advertising. I thought that it could've been a good movie, but ended up being referred to as THE WORST animated movie in the 2010's decade, and maybe even one of the worst movies of all (even outside of animation) of the 2010's decade. 1/10 for the story, 2/10 for the animation, 1/10 for the characters. My overall ranking: 1/10. Shame on you, Sony Pictures Animation. I thought you could do better than this.

Is the first animated Razzie Award winner The Emoji Movie the worst film of the year? Gene (T.J. Miller) is the ‚Äòmeh' emoji inside a kid's iPhone who wants to be a wide variety of expressions. Once he accidentally glitches the phone, he crosses the threshold and exits Textropolis with his band of misfits Hi-5 (James Corden) and Jailbreak (Anna Faris), going through all sorts of Apps like CandyCrush, Just Dance, Spotify, and Dropbox, to escape from the bots hired by Smiler (Maya Rudolph). The obvious message in the film is that technology connects people together, so buy an iPhone and text an emoji to show your love for another. Hearing that flimsy and gimmicky moral, I saw The Emoji Movie as a 90-minute commercial for Sony products, with all the features installed such as a half-baked story, uninspired characters, and obnoxious puns, but colorful imaginative worlds. As for Alex, the phone's owner who sends a text to let go of his comfort zone, he is no Riley from Inside Out. The boy is just as dreadfully boring as all the other phone-ridden schoolmates, including his girl crush, and the apps and emojis don't do much to support his character arc. Also, the film missed an opportunity to have the emojis escape the phone world and enter the WiFi network, where they might accidentally damage the system causing chaos in not just the school but the world. This could have been a unique children's satire tackling the impact of technology among humans. However, The Emoji Movie and Sony exist to only advertise trendy electronics rather than glorifying the art of cinema. (1 ¬Ω Thumbs Down Symbols out of 5)

This movie is so "bad" that, philosophically, it starts to make you question what makes a "bad" movie, and what the different types of bad are. This movie is probably bad in the worst way possible - it's empty and soulless. This isn't art. This isn't something that tried and missed it's mark. It's a manufactured product using a store-bought just-add-water story. It's the cinematic equivalent of a TV dinner. Now, TV dinners are edible but are they really nourishing? This movie isn't a "failure". The story is fine and complete. But it's soulless.

An awful animated film on all accounts. The fact that there are product placements isn't the issue, but the fact that they take up the majority of the movie and replace the story ruin it. Not a single joke gets a laugh, not a single actor tries at all, not a single story beat will change your perspective, the plot holes are numerous given the lack of plot, the animation is not spectacular, and no creativity is put into the world that could have been very inventive. The only plus to the film is the glimmers of social commentary about replacing activity with technology. However, a film about emojis was the wrong place for this. Overall, young kids will like it fine, but I think this is the worst animated film of all time (excluding Foodfight).

To be fair, you have to have a very high IQ to understand The Emoji Movie. The humour is extremely subtle, and without a solid grasp of theoretical physics most of the jokes will go over a typical viewer's head. There's also Gene's nihilistic outlook, which is deftly woven into his characterisation- his personal philosophy draws heavily from Shakespearen literature, for instance. The fans understand this stuff; they have the intellectual capacity to truly appreciate the depths of these jokes, to realise that they're not just funny- they say something deep about LIFE. As a consequence people who dislike The Emoji Movie truly ARE idiots- of course they wouldn't appreciate, for instance, the humour in Poop's existential catchphrase "Haha! We are number two!" which itself is a cryptic reference to Turgenev's Russian epic Fathers and Sons. I'm smirking right now just imagining one of those addlepated simpletons scratching their heads in confusion as Tony Leondis' genius wit unfolds itself on their television screens. What fools.. how I pity them. üòÇ

I don't like this movie as a serious piece at all. But this movie is brilliant. The jokes are not funny. There are long "Just Dance" and "Candy Crush" portions that are giant advertisements. The plot and moral of the story is stale and unoriginal. But I don't see why people would go into this movie expecting a masterpiece with thoughtful writing. On the other hand, the animation is incredible and is ironically hilarious as there is no subtly about how dumb of an idea the movie really is and it shows with how hilarious the execution is. And that is what makes this movie great. If you see this as a satirical view into the meaninglessness of the topic itself, you will have plenty of laughs at the self-aware execution of how horrible it is to have a movie about emojis.
